friends out of enemies, and brings
romance to estranged sweethearts.

of a feud between the families of old
Charles Sellon and Charles Richman.

up.

forces under their Emperor Saladin
are stronger than they had expected,
and their resistance checks the tide
of the invasion at Acre for many
weeks.

right-wing literary critics has not always Men too
clear. Objectivity and keen sanity have not always

hazy atmosphere and renew. the vitality of both the
manner and content of literary criticism. The flaccid
sentimentalists like William Lyons Phelps, Isabel Patterson, and Herschel Brickell, have shown their true
colors by retreating behind a cloud of pointless slander,
but the more intelligent of the critics, Krutch and Cowley, for example, have taken up the challenge sincerely
and objectively. The result has been a purer literary
atmosphere, -more conducive to creative effort and the
clarity of literary criteria.
Put broadly and most reasonably, the chief claim
of the left-wing critics is that'literary productions tse
judged by the degree of understanding of social forces
displayed therein. Sound technique and convincing reality of character are not however dispensed with as
bourgeois superfluities. On the contrary, the radicalminded critics contend that the broad comprehension by

gives more vital and organic meaning to his technique
and delineation of character; that an understanding of
the dynamics of social change Makes possible a fuller
and clearer conception of individual character and a
sounder development of the chosen theme; that, in fine,
these three ingredients of good literature are so vitally
connected that -the absence of one results inevitably in
the weakening of the others.
The question of propaganda. in art is beside the
point. A really great novel, according to the abovementioned criteria, cannot but be good propaganda. It
drives home mercilessly the necessity of the next step
in the scale of social progress. A bad novel, however
forcefully contentious, remains a bad work of art and
therefore fails in its conscious purpose.

but the more intelligent of the critics, Krutch and Cowley, for example, have taken up the challenge sincerely
and objectively. The result has been a purer literary
atmosphere, -more conducive to creative effort and the
clarity of literary criteria.
